content.description: Start on two underclings and toe hooks, bop out to the large pinch then to a small hold on the lip and top out over the scary slab. Another Randy Burks problem and an eliminate...if you see him ask about the name....
content.location: At the top of the powercut clearing walk over the hill, past the main boulders, and down the back side of the hill... on the right just past two long sectons of rock is an overhang... the far side of the overhang.

content.description: Nice lowball for the timid virgin outdoor climber. start on the nice flat starting hold and bump hands up onto slopey crimpy edges. Not bad but not worth spending lots of time on.
content.location: The first boulder on your right when you come out of the woods on the trail approaching the Powercut.

content.description: Start the same as the other wave problems but stay along the right arete throwing to good pocket edges, than manage an absolutely ruinously slopey topout
Start low on jugs and traverse left before going up avoiding the worst of the overhanging curve.
content.location: Lat: 40.5626   Long: -77.8547   Its the back side of Glorious Holes.

content.description: Start the same as wave left but blast up through the center for a slightly easier topout.

The line starts underneath the boulder in the cave. Two hand start on an undercling, go left hand to a perfect shallow pinch and work upwards trying not to dab on the boulder at your back. This line exits on the right side of the boulder, there is a line that starts on the same hold and goes left, likely V10. Skeptical of if either have been climbed, due to how frail most of the rock was underneath. Took a long time to clean off broken/loose rock from very obvious holds. Please let me know if they have been climbed prior. Both are great lines.
content.protection: Pads, just be mindful that you will likely dab on the pads.
content.location: Walk up to the power cut area, the underneath the largest boulder to the left of the power lines (not the two highballs to the left)

content.description: from the top of the hill at the power cut, walk right past two formations to the warm up boulder with the nice start rail on the right... below this on the down hill side facing the road... climb up the overhang on the right side....
Start to the right of The First Will Be Last, traverse right to the good face at the top of the 'hill.'
content.location: Start to the right of The First Will Be Last, on the Church Boulder.

content.description: Those three stacked bulges...climb them. Use slopers and edges to pull through the awkwardness.

A fun problem to warm up on or if climbing solo.  Start on the obvious jug, feet scrunched up on the shelf close to the ground.  If you're feeling spry, you can start on some crimps even lower and feet spread out, bumping this to a V2/2+.
content.location: Head NE along the orange blazes from the powercut.  Pass the Three Amigos on your left (coordinates provided on that page) and continue another thirty feet or so.  This will be directly on your left, close to an orange trail blaze.

content.description: Start with the same to moves as "lowering the bar" then use the arete to turn yourself over and grab a pocket on the face. Easy finish to topout, but watch for crumbly rock. Knee bar shelf is off.
content.location: Main powercut area

content.description: One move wonder. Start low and right on the the boulder with feet underneath. work hands left along the rail. Put a toe or heal near the start hold, then mantle and lunge hard for a pocket edge. Top out.
content.location: On the Turtle boulder in the main powercut area.

content.description: This is a large boulder face with many routes up, all of them between V0 and V2.
content.protection: Nice flat landing zone a single pad should be fine.
content.location:
Lat: 40.5628   Long: -77.8546 

  Head right at the powercut and stay on top of the ridge until you hit it,

content.description: Start matched on the slopey rail down low. The crux is pulling off the ground through the first 3 moves. Finding tiny feet is important to not dabbing the start. The end lets up a bit in difficulty but is not trivial.
content.location: the first boulder on your left once you walk to the right of the powercut. Sort of under Electric Arete and Induction.

content.description: Easy low to the ground boulder. Beta: Route itself has a "crux" reaching around the rock to a right hand that is marked with an "x" in the photos. I wedged my heel into the crack on the side. Topout is flat and awkward but very do-able. Other people have definitely climbed this before (Theres youtube videos of people doing different routes) but there's probably an extra 100 routes at hunters not posted yet, so post away.
content.location: At the powercut Y, Take the trail left, there's a campfire directly before the boulder. Its to the right side of the trail. A short walk from Looks like a turtle and all the other power cut climbs. Maybe 20 yards. Its before Recovery cave. As a side note, there's a plethora of potential all around.

content.description: The overhanging left corner of the ribcage boulder. Start on a sidepull at waist height and work up through more sidepulls and pockets.

Climb up the right tilting slightly bulged arete. Start with hands all the way at the bottom. get creative with toes and heels on the arete to prevent swinging off the first move or two. Fairly easy topout.
content.location:
Lat:40.5628   Long:-77.8546 

  Head right from the power cut, facing the side of the hill away from the road. A gps coordinate compatible device will be helpful.

content.description: Start on the obvious yellowish jug/pocket. Go up for a move or two and then traverse left on pockets. Pull up to a crimp or slopey jug to gain the face of the climb. Drop off or step off the boulder to the side if you don't want the top out be warned it is a very tall topout and a serious no fall zone. Its dirty and sandy up there as well. A classic climb just be careful.
content.protection: Couple of pads and a spotter
content.location: Main powercut area. Adjacent overhanging face to the left of Electric Arete.

content.description: Start matched on the obvious undercling on the lower left corner of the arete. Bump left hand up to the arete with the thumb catch pocket. Reach into the slopey underside of the arete to find a decent crimp/sidepull. Bring your right foot the the protruding corner of the underside of the boulder and secure a knee bar, then use pockets/sidepulls and the arete to pull up and top out.
content.location: In the front of the Powercut Area

content.description: Sit start on a good pinch and go up. Pretty straightforward for this one.
content.location: Follow the trail to the right of the Three Amigos boulder and this will be on your left shortly after the amigos.

content.description: This boulder is low enough to the ground that you can go padless if you want. Start low and to the right with your feet and legs under the boulder. traverse left and eventually swing a heel around the corner. Getting up can be a struggle but work on it.
content.protection: A pad if you're the nervous type
content.location: Powercut main area. Facing the road.

content.description: A proud line, and full value at the grade.Start low on the iron plated huecos, and work up the line that follows the "gulley" in the rock. Slopey weird scary topout, but a clean fall until you really commit to pulling over the bulge...then don't fall.
content.protection: 2 pads or more and a spotter
content.location: Walk to the back of the powercut main area and turn right, following the rock face to where it descends into the "den". It might be a little tricky to find your first time but once you see it it's obvious.

content.description: An overhanging, long, easy, lowball, classic climb. Start on the juggy rails under Electric Arete. Traverse up and right following the line of holds, then reach up and left to a full hand hueco. Finisher move and crux is throwing for a slopey edge with a seam in the back. Match and manage the weird topout. Difficulty of the finishing move is highly height/wingspan dependent.
content.location: Powercut Main area. Starts under Electric Arete, Finishes over top of Repulsion.

content.description: Most obvious problem on the boulder...start on crack/break under the large suspended boulder (same as Agathon), left hand to a small gnarly pinch and right hand to a good but small incut crimp, long right hand move to shallow pinch then the crux - go again to hueco. Or throw from pinch & crimp to hueco...avoiding the dab is the crux this way. Slopers and/or dishes to the mantle top out (same as Agathon).
content.protection: A few pads (although they might just get in the way for the crux).
content.location: Down at the lowest point of the underbelly of the Hunger Artist boulder.

content.description: Start from the hueco jug of Hunger Artist and finish as normal.  Awesome movement, but a bit short.
content.location: Big hueco jug in the middle of the Hunger Artist boulder.

content.description: Climb up the right side of the face of the rib cage boulder.
content.location: On the rib cage boulder

content.description: Start far left and low on a bowling ball sloper jug. traverse to the right across the openings in the rocks until you gain the ledge at the top of the Wave boulder. Optional R rated v1 finish to the top of the spire part.

Extension which adds ~12 moves that climb into The First Church of Appliantology. Power-endurance traverse...more like a route than a problem...should feel about 5.12c/d  depending on your beta. Start on the Eastern (most downhill) side of the boulder on the far right.  Traverses left and around the corner into the 3rd move of The First Church, then continues to the same eliminate topout.
content.protection: A few pads (slid by a spotter) for the committing moves, none if you know when to step off.
content.location: The Church Boulder, walk down the hill alongside the First Church of Appliantology, past the start of that problem and around the corner.  See linked video for beta on where the line goes.

content.description: The main line on the Church boulder - starting on the Southern side of the boulder (the side closest to the road and the powercut) - sit start left hand on a 2-3 finger pocket and right on a bucket. Left toe and Right heel hook, move right up to an ok pinch, big(ish) move left to a bad pocket-edge/gaston formation, match, then follow pockets left and around the corner until the large diagonal crack on the west face, topout. The last moves are eliminates and also the crux.
content.protection: A few pads that can be slid along the traverse by a spotter.
content.location: To get to the Church boulder: From the powercut, head Northeast into the woods on the trail marked with a sign labelled "Bypass." After about 50 feet, cut right into the woods off the trail. Walk for approx. 150 feet over a moderately beaten path over fallen wood until you reach a boulder sitting on the sloping hill.

content.description: Highball.  Sit start under the large arete directly in the power cut on the right side.  Climb out from under the "roof" section and up the arete of the boulder.  Highball but great holds.
content.protection: Pads and spotters as this climb is tall and probably sandy unless it sees a large increase in traffic.
content.location: At the top of the Power cut on the right side.  You can't miss it.

content.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wlc6KlHOIkA https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SaWaZq9dTKMStart on the obvious orange rail in the cave, with feet in the horizontal roof out left. I moved right hand up to sloping nub. A hard heel on the rail and toe scum in the roof marks the crux (for me) to a left had crimp. From there opposing gastons to sloper pinches up and left. Give it a go and let me know what you think, I hate grading routes. I did not use the detached boulder at the start in the cave.........The first video is not the beta, the second video is
content.protection: I used two pads, strung to an anchor at the top of the boulders, see photos. I built the anchor with a black, blue, and pink tricam. Three/ four pads would be way better. Also, I found a snake skin and rather deep hole so keep an eye open for critters.
content.location: In the middle-ish of the 3 sisters area, basically behind electric arete. Get on top of those boulders and look for a steep open cave with a parallel boulder making a decent landing. It more or less on top of Leaving the Den

content.description: Start low on rail to the left of bulge, throw left hand up to a solid hold on top. Bring feet to rail and use various right hands to straddle your way to the top out.The route can be continued in a second pitch that is mostly trivial but adds some more height. Adding this turns the route into "Over-encumbered".
content.location: To the left side of the Hunger Artist cave if you are looking down into it.

content.description: The interesting small overhanging quartzite face to the left of Looks Like a Turtle. Start on the obvious juggy edge at the bottom. Pull up to a crimp, then throw for a high right crimp. search for hold to manage the top out.
content.location: Main Powercut area. Left of Looks like a Turtle.

content.description: Start as for Agathon but climb up and right, staying left of the crack (eliminate), topout  straight up face. Fun problem.
content.location: On the 'backside' of the Hunger Artist boulder.

content.description: Start pinching low on the corner, work up the arete until you can reach to the huecos on the left face. Follow the diagonal line of huecos up and left to an uncomfortable insecure topout. No easy way down off of this one, best to put pads near the end of the climb for a controlled drop off the top after.
content.location:
Lat: 40.5630   Long: -77.8544 

  On the Northwest side of the ridge (facing away from the road), not too much further from the powercut than the ribcage boulder.

content.description: to the right of agape...
Highball. Stand start to the left of Electric Arete - starting holds at ~7 feet up.  Climb the face to the left of the arete, up and near the top head right, topout using the arete.
content.protection: Pads, spotters.  This is a highball climb.
content.location: At the top of the Power cut on the right side.   Starts just to the left of the Electric Arete, sit start.

content.description: Start low on good holds and follow them up the little pinnacle.
content.location: Between glorious holes and mariarete, facing west.

content.description: Start low in the cave, with an uncomfortable rock basically right under your butt.  Start on the large chalked hold right in front of your face and head up and slightly left.  Move out left to a pinch, right up to a sloper, left to a diagonal slot, right to a diagonal crimp rail, left to a crimp above that, and up to a jug and top out.
content.location:
Down in the pit to the left of the Recovery Cave. 

  The Recovery Cave boulder is unavoidable if you follow the trail up the powercut to the left, going past The Hunger Artist down the Ridgeline, bearing to the right when the trail forks.

content.description: Start in crack on the opposite side of the boulder than the topout of the Hunger Artist, throw left to tiny edges to head underneath the boulder, then follow holds staying tight as to not dab on the boulder underneath you as you keep to the side of the boulder with the rock underneath you (stay to the right of the hueco jug for the original variation of this climb) and head to slopers and a slopey mantle topout (same topout as Hunger Artist).  Large dab factor present at all times on this climb.
content.protection: A pad for the start and possibly one for a spotter to move onto the boulder underneath you after you've squeezed through the underbelly of the climb.
content.location: On the low face of the Hunger Artist boulder (opposite of the topout of the Hunger Artist).

content.description: At the far end of the boulder, start sitting with your right hand in an undercling bucket, left on whatever works.  Move up left to a small but good edge, up right to a sidepull pinch, then left into a two-finger "bullet hole" pocket, then right hand under-cling pinch. Avoid the crack leading up the boulder on your right (the jug holds). Move up left through a good sidepull pocket and a small right hand sidepull before topping out just above a small boulder (perched on the stone slope).  Technically an eliminate but a good one.  The v7 version of this line was the original version before the good pocket high and left was discovered and cleaned.  Very few people climb the line this way now, but if you feel like a taste of the past feel free to avoid the good pocket before the topout.
content.protection: Several pads (helps to have some propped up on the slab for a fall at the top).
content.location: From the Recovery cave head left down the trail around the boulder.  Follow the trail to the right and walk to the far end of the gully-like pathway between an overhanging boulder on your right and a slab on your left.  The climb is on the overhanging face.

content.description: The Powercut area at Hunter's Rocks.
